title: CDC and WHO On Top Of Things - "Too Late"

content: "Prevention said on Friday it was too late to contain the swine flu outbreak in the United States. CDC acting director Dr. Richard Besser told reporters in a telephone briefing it was likely too late to try to contain the outbreak, by vaccinating, treating or isolating people. "There are things that we see that suggest that containment is not very likely," he said. He said the U.S. cases and Mexican cases are likely the same virus. "So far the genetic elements that we have looked at are the same." But Besser said it was unclear why the virus was causing so many deaths in deaths in Mexico and such mild disease in the United States. - CDC "http://www.cdc.gov/swineflu/" "Swine Influenza (Flu) Swine Influenza (swine flu) is a respiratory disease of pigs caused by type A influenza that regularly cause outbreaks of influenza among pigs. Swine flu viruses do not normally infect humans, however, human infections with swine flu do occur, and cases of human-to-human spread of swine flu viruses has been documented. "

content: OK, as of this morning there were less than TEN cases in the US - none fatal - and more in Mexico, some fatal. How, exactly, is this a "wasted" agency and world organization? Would you have even known about the disease, how it's spread, how to prevent it, or that there is even a vaccine for it without the existence of the CDC or WHO? You wouldn't even have been able to post a link or quote without either one. Sometime's you can be an idiot, CJ.

Science can ameliorate epidemics, can't always stop them. But most people aren't dead of AIDS last time I checked. Dave

content: Sorry, I will not have time to do a follow up on this so ya all are going to just have to do your own research. WITHIN DAYS of the CDC (Atlanta) receiving a virus sample from the Mexican Government, the CDC defined this virus as totally new... and totally unique. We are about ten days downrange from that date if memory serves. The states of Texas and California didn't know they were dealing with a new virus either as there have only been 2-3 cases reported (as of now) since the CDC made its declaration. San Diego County and Imperial County (on the mexican border) in California... and one single city in Texas are the only known US cases. Again... this information has only arisen AFTER the Mexican Government sent CDC the sample for identification. Prior to that Mexico was thinking that they just had an outbreak of an existing flu type. But now that government is taking rather strict actions to limit its further spread... actions that the CDC thinks may be too late. As for the mortality rate... no one has died in the USA. Perhaps because we have better medical aid for the most part. In Mexico a little under 1100 cases have been identified so far since testing for the exact CDC confirmed virus began. Of taht at LEAST 62 deaths have already resulted. That is roughly 6% mortality rate... That is very high by US standards. Again it is not known exactly how many deats or infections there actually are in Mexico at this point. too much is never reported there. BTW: say 100 million Americans get exposed to this new virus... do you think a 5% or 6% mortality rate could be realistic? I am not certain myself. My fear is that Mexico is NOT ground zero for this virus strain. I am kind of worried that it originated in points south of Mexico where reporting is almost non-existant. And for a few more months I have loved ones down there... working it the area where viruses incubate and are easily transmitted. There is no cure or prevention for this swine flu bug. All one can do is ride it out. Not the best answer for a warm and fuzzy feeling.

content: "Welcome to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For over 60 years, CDC has been dedicated to protecting health and promoting quality of life through the prevention and control of disease, injury, and disability. We are committed to programs that reduce the health and economic consequences of the leading causes of death and disability, thereby ensuring a long, productive, healthy life for all people. " This should read: For Over 60 Years The CDC and us fat cat government employees have been bilking the American Tax payer for every dime we can get. Although We are suppose to be "promoting quality of life through the prevention and control of disease, injury, and disability" that's just a BS statement that makes it sound like were something other than just another beaoruocratic government agency that is more worried about political outcome and job security than our actuall stated mission". In the mean time hundreds are dying and the Borders are not closed so this crap is going to spread all over the world, where is the CDC now when they are needed the most? I know...to busy making dumb 10 line news articles that simple say "Hey we found this, but found it to late, lots of luck to you habre".

content: quote: Worries that the new swine flu strain that has killed as many as 68 people and sickened more than 1,000 across Mexico has “pandemic potential” increased with the announcement that the virus had spread to Kansas, and likely to New York City. On Saturday, two new cases of swine flu were confirmed in Kansas. And New York City Health Commissioner Dr. Thomas Frieden announced that tests showed that eight New York schoolchildren had a type A influenza virus that was likely the swine flu. California, Texas, Kansas, New York.....and these are just the ones we know about.

content: I recently discovered that Kroger has started selling beef and pork that is from Mexico. I no longer buy either from them. Just how many other places get either from Mexico? I tend to trust them more at keeping my food safe.

content: quote: Originally posted by peter3_1: Remind us again, Dave , of how an influenza virus and the aids virus spread? How are they similar, and how are they different? Comparing applea and handgrenades again? Quiet right to say this Peter, but I was pointing out that you cannot prevent new diseases from mutating into existance. Just what can the CDC do to stop mutations? And no one even knew that AIDS was a disease. This was because AIDS doesn't kill you, other diseases take advantage of your lower immune system to do that. Everyone seems to have forgotten this about AIDS. On this thread the CDC is being blamed for not acting sooner - Heck, no one even knew this was occuring. There are now eight confirmed cases in New York. Kids "flew" to Mexico on some sort of arranged trip - Didn't "cross" any borders. So is the CDC responsible for not acting when they had nothing to act on? Schid happens. Dave
